data.title: We by Yevgeny Zamyatin, First Edition
data.meta_description: We (Evergreens) by Yevgeny Zamyatin and a great selection of related books, art and collectibles available now at AbeBooks.com.
data.text:
Hardcover. Condition: Fair. No Jacket. First UK Edition. First UK Printing [Jonathan Cape, london, 1970]; 285pp; grey cloth, black topstain, gold titling to spine, 1cm tears at head, library sticker residue near base, ex-library [South Australian Institute Of Technology] with stamps on foredge, ffep, title page & copyright page, jacket blurb taped to inside front board, bookseller sticke, tape marks, library card pouch at rear. A solid, albeit vandalised, copy. Translated by Bernard Guilbert Guerney. Introduction & Bibliographical note by Michael Glenny. We has a complicated publishing history but, in short & to place this edition in context: Written in 1920, the manuscript was sent to Zamyatin's Berlin publishers who made it available for translation by Gregory Zilboorg into English & published by Dutton, New York in 1924. Also translated into Czech & French in 1927 & 1928. First published in original Russian by the Chekhov Press [NY, 1952]. This [Guerney] translation into English was first published in New York in 1960 & is the preferred version - this book is the first UK printing of the Guerney translation.

Hardcover. Condition: Very Good. FIRST EDITION. 1970 Jonathan Cape first UK hardcover translation. A nice copy; very good condition. in good dustjacket. Light reading wear, a little wear to edges of dustjacket and a small amount of scuffing to corners. This landmark novel was first published in the 1920s and is thought to have been the model both for 'Brave New World' and '1984'. The book is housed in a custom made slipcase covered in purple cloth and lined with cream acid-free archival paper.

Cloth. Condition: Near Fine. Dust Jacket Condition: Very Good. First British Edition. Near Fine, small corner and edge bumps, prior owner bookplate and blindstamp at front end pages, two small spots fore edge. In a Very Good dust wrapper, small chips and rubs at spine ends and corners. A science fiction classic, one of the the grandfathers of the satirical futuristic dystopia genre, WE was banned in Russia in 1921and first published in English in 1924 by E. P. Dutton in New York in a translation by Gregory Zilboorg. The German TV network ZDF adapted the novel for a TV movie in 1982, under the German title Wir (English: WE). Size: 8vo - over 7¾" - 9¾" tall.

[Dystopia] FIRST UK EDITION, first impression. Octavo (21 x 14cm), pp.285 [3]. Publisher's grey cloth with gilt titles to spine. Top edge black. With the striking purple dust-jacket designed by Stanley Chapman, priced at 35s / £1.75. A crisp, clean copy, with just a little rubbing to jacket edges. Near fine. Russian novelist Yevgeny Zamyatin's masterpiece: "a remarkable Utopian fantasy, a landmark in world literature, the precursor of and almost certainly the model for 'Brave New World' and '1984'. We is an icily etched portrait of a dehumanized society of the future with its ubiquitous timetables, days set aside for sexual activities, glass-box living accommodation and ever-alert watch-dog police, presided over by 'The Benefactor'" (from the blurb). The novel was banned by the new Soviet censorship bureau in 1921 and was first published, in English, in New York in 1924. A Czech language edition followed, where it was condemned by a state-sponsored literary group. Zamyatin was seen as a dissident, his subsequent literary output suppressed, and eventually he personally wrote to Stalin to request exile rather than starve at home. This translation preceded the first Russian edition, which did not appear until 1988.
